definitions: having undergone a chemical reaction with oxygen, changing molecular structure
having lost shine or brightness through exposure to air and moisture
examples: The oxidized copper roof had turned a distinctive green color
Scientists studied the oxidized compounds in the laboratory sample
The oxidized silver jewelry needed careful polishing and cleaning
He found oxidized metal parts throughout the abandoned machinery

definitions: characterized by peace, tranquility, and absence of conflict or violence
of, relating to, or bordering the Pacific Ocean region
examples: Her pacific nature helped resolve the heated dispute calmly
The pacific settlement avoided years of costly litigation
Pacific islands attract millions of tourists each year worldwide
The Pacific coast experiences frequent seismic activity and tsunamis

definitions: believing in or advocating for peaceful resolution of conflicts without violence
relating to the doctrine that war and violence are unjustifiable
examples: The pacifist movement gained momentum during the Vietnam War
His pacifist beliefs prevented him from military service
They adopted pacifist principles in their protest strategies
The pacifist approach emphasized dialogue over confrontation

definitions: wrapped, boxed, or contained in packaging for storage or sale
organized and presented as a complete, ready-made unit or set
examples: The packaged foods filled several aisles of the supermarket
All packaged items must display nutritional information clearly
The packaged tour included flights, hotels, and guided excursions
They offered packaged solutions for small business software needs

definitions: completely filled with people, leaving little or no empty space
pressed or squeezed tightly together into a confined space
having belongings arranged in luggage and ready for a journey
examples: The packed stadium erupted when the home team scored
Every packed train during rush hour tests commuters' patience
The packed snow made perfect conditions for skiing today
Tightly packed boxes filled the entire storage unit
With bags packed, they waited eagerly for their taxi
She kept her suitcase packed for emergency trips

definitions: lined or stuffed with soft material for protection or comfort
dishonestly increased or exaggerated to appear more substantial than reality
examples: The padded chair provided excellent support for long meetings
Children wore padded helmets during their skating lessons
The padded expense report raised suspicions during the audit
His padded resume included several fictional job experiences

definitions: of or relating to the medical care and treatment of infants and children
examples: The paediatric ward specialized in treating childhood diseases
She completed her paediatric residency at the children's hospital
Paediatric dosages must be carefully calculated by patient weight
The paediatric nurse had special training in child psychology

definitions: relating to religions other than Christianity, Judaism, or Islam
showing lack of religious belief or indulging in sensual pleasures
examples: Ancient pagan rituals celebrated the changing of seasons
The pagan temples were converted into Christian churches
Their pagan lifestyle shocked the conservative community members
The festival retained some pagan elements despite Christian influence

definitions: receiving money as payment for work or services provided
having been settled, discharged, or compensated with money
examples: The paid staff worked alongside many volunteer helpers
She finally got a paid internship after months of searching
All paid invoices were filed in the completed folder
The paid vacation benefit attracted many job applicants

definitions: showing or expressing physical pain or discomfort
showing mental or emotional distress, hurt, or disappointment
examples: His pained grimace revealed the severity of his injury
She walked with a pained expression after the accident
Her pained look showed how the criticism had hurt
His pained silence spoke volumes about his disappointment

definitions: causing physical pain, discomfort, or bodily suffering
causing emotional or mental distress, anguish, or sorrow
requiring considerable effort, difficulty, or tedious attention to complete
examples: The painful injury required immediate medical attention
Her painful arthritis made daily tasks extremely difficult
Watching the painful documentary brought many viewers to tears
The painful memories still haunted him years later
The painful process of data entry took several weeks
Learning the new system was painful but ultimately worthwhile

definitions: not causing or involving physical pain or discomfort
accomplished easily without difficulty, stress, or unpleasant consequences
examples: The dentist promised a painless procedure using local anesthetic
Modern techniques make most surgeries relatively painless
The painless registration process took only five minutes online
Switching providers proved surprisingly painless with their help

definitions: done with or employing great care, thoroughness, and attention to detail
examples: The painstaking restoration took archaeologists over five years
Her painstaking research uncovered previously unknown historical facts
The artist's painstaking attention to detail impressed critics
Painstaking efforts were made to preserve the ancient manuscript

definitions: covered or decorated with paint or similar coating material
having makeup applied, especially heavily or noticeably
examples: The freshly painted walls brightened the entire room
Painted furniture can transform an outdated piece completely
Her painted lips stood out against her pale complexion
The heavily painted actress looked unrecognizable off stage

definitions: arranged or occurring in sets of two
matched or coupled together for a specific purpose or relationship
examples: The paired columns flanked the grand entrance hall
Paired chromosomes separate during cell division process
Students were paired for the collaborative research project
The paired wines complemented each course perfectly

definitions: having a pleasant or acceptable taste, flavor, or texture
acceptable, agreeable, or satisfactory to one's sensibilities or preferences
examples: The chef made the healthy food more palatable with herbs
The medicine's palatable flavor helped children take it willingly
They tried making the proposal more palatable to voters
The palatable compromise satisfied both negotiating parties

definitions: resembling a palace in being spacious, magnificent, or luxurious
examples: The palatial estate featured marble floors and crystal chandeliers
They stayed in palatial suites overlooking the Mediterranean Sea
The company's palatial headquarters impressed visiting clients significantly
Her palatial home contained over twenty bedrooms

definitions: light in color or having little color saturation
having an unhealthy lack of color in the face from illness or emotion
lacking in strength, force, or significance when compared to something else
examples: The pale blue walls created a calming bedroom atmosphere
She wore a pale pink dress to the spring wedding
He looked pale after hearing the shocking news
The pale patient clearly needed immediate medical attention
His achievements pale beside his brother's Olympic medals
The movie's special effects pale compared to modern standards

definitions: relating to the earliest period of the Stone Age, characterized by primitive stone tools
examples: Paleolithic cave paintings revealed early human artistic expression
The paleolithic tools were carefully preserved in the museum
Paleolithic humans were primarily hunter-gatherers living in small groups
Scientists discovered paleolithic artifacts dating back 40,000 years

definitions: providing relief from symptoms without dealing with the underlying cause
designed to alleviate pain and suffering without providing a cure
examples: Palliative care focused on improving the patient's quality of life
The palliative treatment eased her pain but couldn't cure the disease
They offered only palliative measures rather than real solutions
The palliative approach helped manage symptoms during final months

definitions: abnormally pale, typically because of poor health or emotional distress
lacking in vitality, force, or conviction; feeble or insipid
examples: His pallid complexion suggested he hadn't been outside in months
The pallid child clearly needed medical attention immediately
The actor gave a pallid performance lacking any emotion
Her pallid attempt at humor fell flat with the audience

definitions: able to be touched or felt, especially by medical examination
so intense or obvious as to be almost tangible or touchable
examples: The doctor found a palpable lump during the examination
The palpable pulse indicated the patient's heart was beating strongly
The palpable tension in the room made everyone uncomfortable
Their palpable excitement filled the stadium before kickoff

definitions: very small or inadequate in amount; insulting in its insufficiency
examples: The paltry salary barely covered basic living expenses
They offered a paltry sum for the valuable antique
His paltry excuse didn't convince anyone of his innocence
The paltry attendance at the event disappointed organizers greatly

definitions: of, relating to, or affecting the pancreas organ in the digestive system
examples: Pancreatic cancer remains one of the deadliest forms of cancer
The pancreatic enzymes help digest proteins and fats
She underwent pancreatic surgery to remove a benign tumor
Pancreatic disorders can affect both digestion and blood sugar

definitions: occurring over a wide geographic area and affecting an exceptionally high proportion of the population
examples: The pandemic disease spread rapidly across multiple continents
Pandemic preparedness became a global priority after COVID-19
The pandemic influenza of 1918 killed millions worldwide
During pandemic conditions, international travel was severely restricted

definitions: covered or decorated with flat rectangular sections of wood or other material
examples: The paneled library featured rich mahogany wood throughout
Their paneled office walls created a warm professional atmosphere
The wood paneled station wagon was a family classic
Darkly paneled rooms can feel cozy but sometimes oppressive

definitions: experiencing or showing sudden uncontrollable fear or anxiety
done hastily or irrationally as a result of sudden fear
examples: The panicked crowd rushed toward the emergency exits
Her panicked expression revealed she'd forgotten the presentation
His panicked decision to sell proved costly later
The panicked evacuation led to unnecessary injuries

definitions: showing a wide, unobstructed view of an extensive area in all directions
examples: The panoramic windows offered breathtaking mountain views
They took panoramic photographs from the observation deck
The restaurant's panoramic vista attracted tourists year-round
His panoramic understanding of history impressed his students

definitions: of or relating to the Pope or the papacy in the Roman Catholic Church
examples: The papal decree affected Catholic churches worldwide
Papal authority has evolved throughout church history
The papal visit drew thousands of faithful believers
Several papal documents addressed modern social issues

definitions: published as a book with a flexible paper cover rather than hardcover boards
examples: The paperback edition costs much less than the hardcover
She preferred paperback books for traveling because they're lighter
Most bestsellers appear in paperback format after initial release
The paperback version included a new author's introduction

definitions: having a thin, dry texture resembling paper in appearance or feel
examples: The papery skin of the onion peeled away easily
Autumn leaves became papery and brittle before falling
Her papery voice barely rose above a whisper
The ancient document felt papery and fragile to touch

definitions: having the form of a parabola; curved symmetrically about an axis
examples: The parabolic mirror focused sunlight to a single point
Satellite dishes use parabolic shapes to receive signals effectively
The ball followed a parabolic trajectory through the air
Engineers designed parabolic arches for optimal weight distribution

definitions: having the nature of a paradox; seemingly absurd or contradictory but potentially true
examples: The paradoxical situation required creative thinking to resolve
It seems paradoxical that exercise gives you more energy
Her paradoxical statement confused everyone at the meeting
The paradoxical nature of quantum physics challenges common sense

definitions: extending in the same direction and everywhere equidistant, never converging or diverging
similar, comparable, or corresponding in some significant way
examples: The parallel lines never intersect no matter how far extended
Railroad tracks must remain perfectly parallel for safety
Their parallel careers followed remarkably similar trajectories
The parallel developments in both countries surprised historians

definitions: relating to or causing paralysis or loss of movement ability
so drunk as to be unable to move or function properly
examples: The paralytic stroke left him unable to walk
Paralytic shellfish poisoning can be fatal if untreated
He was paralytic after drinking all night at the party
The paralytic man had to be carried home by friends

definitions: affected by paralysis; having lost the ability to move part or all of the body
unable to think or act normally through fear, shock, or overwhelming emotion
examples: The accident left him paralyzed from the waist down
Her paralyzed arm slowly regained function through therapy
She stood paralyzed with fear as the snake approached
The company seemed paralyzed by indecision during the crisis

definitions: organized similarly to a military force but not part of official armed forces
examples: Paramilitary groups operated outside government control
The paramilitary police wore distinctive black uniforms
Their paramilitary training included weapons and tactical exercises
Paramilitary organizations often blur lines between civilian and military

definitions: more important than anything else; supreme in rank, importance, or authority
examples: Safety remains paramount in all construction projects
The paramount concern was protecting civilian lives
Her paramount achievement was winning the Nobel Prize
Customer satisfaction is paramount to business success

definitions: unreasonably or obsessively anxious, suspicious, or mistrustful of others
characterized by or suffering from the mental condition of paranoia
examples: His paranoid behavior alienated friends and family members
She became increasingly paranoid about workplace conspiracies
The paranoid patient required specialized psychiatric treatment
Paranoid delusions made him believe everyone was plotting against him

definitions: denoting events or phenomena that are beyond the scope of normal scientific understanding
examples: Paranormal investigators searched the haunted house for evidence
Many people report paranormal experiences they cannot explain
The paranormal activity increased after midnight each night
Scientists remain skeptical of paranormal claims without proof

definitions: of or relating to Grenada or its people, language, or culture
examples: Grenadian beaches attract thousands of tourists every year
The Grenadian government invested heavily in education reform
Traditional Grenadian cuisine features fresh seafood and spices
Many Grenadian students pursue higher education abroad

definitions: of or relating to Guatemala or its people, language, or culture
examples: Guatemalan coffee ranks among the world's finest varieties
The Guatemalan civil war lasted for thirty-six years
Ancient Guatemalan ruins reveal sophisticated Maya civilization
Traditional Guatemalan textiles display vibrant colors and patterns

definitions: of or relating to Guinea or its people, language, or culture
examples: Guinean bauxite reserves are among the world's largest
The Guinean economy depends heavily on mining exports
Traditional Guinean music influences modern African pop
Many Guinean languages belong to the Mande family

definitions: of or relating to Guyana or its people, language, or culture
examples: Guyanese culture blends African, Indian, and indigenous influences
The Guyanese dollar has fluctuated significantly this year
Many Guyanese speak English as their primary language
Traditional Guyanese dishes reflect the country's diverse heritage

definitions: of or relating to Haiti or its people, language, or culture
examples: Haitian art has gained international recognition and acclaim
The Haitian revolution was the first successful slave revolt
Haitian Creole is spoken by nearly all Haiti's population
Traditional Haitian music combines African and European elements

definitions: of or relating to Hawaii or its people, language, or culture
examples: Hawaiian volcanoes remain among the world's most active
The Hawaiian language experienced a successful revitalization movement
Traditional Hawaiian music features the ukulele and slack-key guitar
Hawaiian cuisine blends Polynesian, Asian, and American influences

definitions: of or relating to the Hebrew language or the ancient Hebrews and their descendants
examples: Hebrew scripture forms the basis of Jewish religious texts
Modern Hebrew became Israel's official language in 1948
The Hebrew alphabet consists of twenty-two consonant letters
Ancient Hebrew inscriptions provide valuable historical information

definitions: of or relating to the German philosopher Hegel or his dialectical philosophy
examples: Hegelian dialectics influenced Marx's theory of historical materialism
The Hegelian concept of thesis-antithesis-synthesis shapes modern thought
Many Hegelian scholars debate the interpretation of absolute spirit
Her Hegelian analysis revealed contradictions in contemporary society

definitions: affected by or relating to paralysis of the legs and lower body
examples: The paraplegic athlete competed in wheelchair basketball championships
Paraplegic patients require specialized rehabilitation and support services
After becoming paraplegic, she advocated for disability rights
The paraplegic ward had specially adapted facilities

definitions: living as a parasite on or within another organism
habitually exploiting the hospitality or generosity of others without giving anything in return
examples: Parasitic worms can cause serious health problems in humans
The parasitic plant drew nutrients from its host tree
His parasitic lifestyle depended entirely on wealthy friends
The parasitic relationship drained company resources without adding value
